case_name: Representation of V Trustees Ltd re K & N Trusts
summary: Trustee self-dealing through inter-trust loans; pervasive conflict led to resignation.
legal_principle: Trustees must not self-deal and must act in the best interests of each trust separately.
holding: Court directed the trustee to resign due to self-dealing and conflicting interests.
key_points: loans made between co‑trusteed family trusts
observed_conduct: Trustee arranged inter‑trust loans with no disclosure or consent from beneficiaries.
anomaly_detected: Unmanaged conflict of interest in invoice of trust assets without oversight.
breached_law_or_rule: General fiduciary duty under Trusts (Jersey) Law 1984, Art. 30
authority_basis: Representation of V Trustees re K & N Trusts [2020] JRC 220 (Bedell Cristin summary)  [oai_citation:6‡Bedell Cristin](https://www.bedellcristin.com/news/2021/trusts-self-dealing-and-conflicts-bedell-cristin-acts-for-successful-beneficiary/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

case_name: In the matter of the Onorati Settlement
summary: Trustees failed to take tax advice and relied on oral beneficiary assurance; appointment set aside.
legal_principle: Trustees must seek proper professional advice and not rely on informal assurances.
holding: Appointment voided; reliance on oral assurances alone is inadequate and breaches fiduciary duty.
observed_conduct: Trustee proceeded with appointment based solely on oral assurance from beneficiary.
anomaly_detected: Failure to verify or obtain tax advice breached duty of care and diligence.
breached_law_or_rule: Fiduciary duty under Trusts (Jersey) Law 1984 and case law on trustee due diligence
authority_basis: In the matter of the Onorati Settlement [2013] JRC 182 (WTLR summary)  [oai_citation:7‡lawjournals.co.uk](https://www.lawjournals.co.uk/wills-trusts-law-reports/re-the-onorati-settlement-2013-jrc-182/?utm_source=chatgpt.com) [oai_citation:8‡Mondaq](https://www.mondaq.com/jersey/trusts/268318/pitt-and-the-pendulum--in-the-matter-of-the-onorati-settlement-2013-jrc-182?utm_source=chatgpt.com) [oai_citation:9‡Walkers](https://www.walkersglobal.com/en/Insights/2025/05/Jersey-Trust-Law-Series---Out-with-the-old-and-in-with-the-new---Removal-of-trustees?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

case_name: Bartlett v Barclays Bank Trust Co Ltd
summary: Trustee failed to supervise a company in which the trust held a controlling stake, leading to speculative losses.
legal_principle: Trustees must exercise care as an ordinary prudent person of business would in managing their own affairs.
holding: Trustee breached duty by not intervening in speculative developments despite control.
key_points: failure to obtain information or intervene
observed_conduct: Trustee passively accepted annual reports and failed to enforce prudent control despite majority shareholding.
anomaly_detected: Lack of active supervision and failure to use controlling position to safeguard trust assets.
breached_law_or_rule: Prudent business standard under common law duty of trustee care (Restated in Trustee Act 2000 s 1)
authority_basis: Brightman J, Bartlett v Barclays Bank Trust Co Ltd [1980] Ch 515 describing trustee oversight obligations.

summary: Constructive trustee imposed for unauthorised control of trust assets.
legal_principle: Equity imposes a constructive trust when property is held unconscionably.
holding: Court imposed a constructive trust on property unlawfully taken into possession.
observed_conduct: Individual exerted unauthorized control over trust assets without authority.
anomaly_detected: Unjust possession and lack of authority triggers trust obligations.
authority_basis: Equity imposes constructive trust for unauthorized possession of trust property.

summary: Fiduciary profited using trust information without beneficiary consent; held liable in constructive trust.
legal_principle: Fiduciaries must not profit from their position unless fully authorized.
holding: Held liable to account for profits; constructive trust imposed despite benefiting the trust.
key_points: use of trust information for personal gain
observed_conduct: Solicitor and beneficiary used trust information to gain a majority share, profiting personally.
anomaly_detected: Use of privileged information for personal gain without informed consent breached fiduciary duty.
breached_law_or_rule: Strict no-profit rule in fiduciary duty
authority_basis: Boardman v Phipps [1966] UKHL 2 House of Lords affirmed strict fiduciary profit accountability.
